utterances: Hello?
You're on the air, Raymond.
Go ahead.
Yes.
I'm just - I was just saying that it's possible they did go ahead and just kill Osama because some of the things that may have been let out in the process of a trial.
So that he may have been trying to surrender and was not allowed to.
Right.

Because in the process of a trial, there were some things that United States didn't want to be known to the general public, some of the things that were done that were not really lawful and did not want to be known.
So they just went ahead and took care of the whole situation.
It seems unlikely to me that he would have known things that Khalid Sheikh Mohammed does not.
But anyway, Jeff Greenfield, well, might that have been the case?
Well, I mean, I think you - I think one of the inevitable results of whatever happened was that a - this is like the most amazingly fertile ground for the growth of conspiracy theories.

I mean, if one believes that Osama was in league with the Bush administration to pull off 9/11 - and, you know, you have to forgive me, I don't think one is neutral about that opinion, I think you either are on planet Earth or you are not - then that makes sense.

I mean, it's certainly, by the way, the classic part of conspiracy plots - I mean, I'm talking here about in fiction, is you always knock off somebody in the middle of the conspiracy because they know too much.

You know, it's always - if you're ever watching a movie about a conspiracy, the unbilled actor who plays the number four conspirator, he's not going to be in that movie very long because sooner or later the bad guy, or the worst guy, is gonna bump him off because of what he knows...
Dan...
Yeah, I'm sorry.
I just have an email from Dan in St. Louis: What if Osama had been taken alive?
Then we would have gagged him, cuffed him and put a bag over his head, we would have spirited him away in the dead of night to a secret prison in Afghanistan for torture and interrogation.
Then the president would hold a news conference to announce he had been killed.
We would all believe he's dead and he would never be seen or heard from again except by the select interrogators or torturers at the secret prison.
OK.

Like I say, you know, I mean when I did my book on counterfactual history, I really did try hard to hew to as plausible scenarios as I could by interviewing people and grounding it in what I considered factual possibility.
But I think, if I may interpret this email, I think this person is making a point about some of the, quote, enhanced interrogation techniques that have caused so much controversy.
But that's one of the other interesting things is - about a bin Laden, you put him in a military commission or military tribunal - that takes years.
And then, even in military tribunals, you know, the defendant has certain rights.
I guess shedding, I guess, the expectations of what they think I am, you know?
Mm-hmm.
I don't know how open a military tribunal might be.
Apparently there's some flexibility as to whether they're open or closed.
Do you permit any witnesses to those trials?
Do you permit any reporters in those trials?
And if no, then you're going to get people saying, you know, you guys are a bunch of hypocrites.
You're talk about the rule of law.
Even while other people say, why are you letting this man live?
He's, you know, being able to pray, he's being fed, he's being clothed, and this is this guy who gleefully murdered as many Americans as possible.
I think it would have been a no-win situation.
Jeff Greenfield's piece in The Washington Post is titled: ""What If bin Laden Had Been Captured, Not Killed?

An Alternate History."" He's also the author of a book of alternate history called ""Then Everything Changed: Stunning Alternate Histories of American Politics: JFK, RFK, Carter, Ford, Reagan."" Jeff Greenfield, thanks very much for your time today.
Thanks for having me, Neal.
Jeff Greenfield with us from our bureau in New York.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
The Trump administration announced plans Monday that would require drugmakers to reveal the list price of their medicines in TV commercials.
The move effectively sets the stage for months or even years of battle with the drug industry.
Kaiser Health News senior correspondent Sarah Jane Tribble covers drug pricing, and she is here to walk us through what this means.
Good morning.
Good morning.
What is this new proposal?
What exactly will it mean?

So what Secretary Azar of Health and Human Services under the Trump administration - he took to the stage yesterday, and he announced that any drug that costs more than $35 a month would need to have advertising on its television ads.
And the rule is rather specific.
It says the advertising needs to be on a contrasting background.
It needs to be easy to read.
So there are a lot of questions embedded in that.
What price are they going to list in the TV commercials?
Because based on how much people pay in insurance, the prices are different for different people, right?
Right, exactly.
So when you go to the pharmacy counter and I go to the pharmacy counter, our copays may be different depending on our insurance, and we may have a deductible we have to fulfill.
So the question is what price will be up there?
The secretary did note that they want list price up there, which is also...
What is it?
...A good question - what does it mean?
He clarified later and said it would be wholesale acquisition cost, which is an industry term where nobody really pays that often.
Alex Azar made a point of saying that the list price does matter, and he did this big analogy with the auto industry on cars and so forth.
And it does matter because it's the base for a lot of negotiation, and it can be a base for what people who are uninsured pay.
But...
Would it matter to consumers, though?
It can be often confusing for consumers, right?

So if I'm told that my drug is $5,000 a month, just for example, but I'm only going to pay a couple thousand dollars a month or my deductible covers it or my health plan covers it and I'm only paying $50 copay, it could scare you away from getting that drug.
Right.
So even though it's kind of confusing, it's still demanding a level of transparency that I imagine the pharmaceutical industry isn't so keen on.
Yeah.
And it is getting a lot of attention.
It's something that is kind of a populist thing that people can grasp onto.
And it is just a few weeks before the midterms, I want to point out, for the November elections, so the timing is very exciting because people really care about prescription drug prices right now.
Recent polling shows it - price transparency on prescription drug prices polls well with American voters.
Just the idea of it, forcing these drug companies to be more forthcoming.
So is it - what's the likelihood that it actually is going to go into effect?
So let me back up just a minute and say the pharmaceutical industry's response because I think that helps lead us to the likelihood of it going into effect.
So yesterday morning before the secretary took to the stage and made this big announcement, the pharma industry through their trade group PhRMA made a big announcement as well.

And they said, hey, we're going to do a voluntary measure where we ask our companies to help educate you about your price, and we will help, you know, direct you on our website to information about the benefits and cost of our drugs.
And they're going to put together a web portal that you can go and look at your insurance options and so forth.
OK.
So that was kind of the pharma industry on the offensive.
During the press call for that, somebody asked, hey, is there a possibility for litigation here?
And the industry didn't say no. And I think it's a legitimate question, and several law scholars that I spoke with yesterday did note that this is just asking for litigation.
So even if the rule comes into being, which you've outlined is kind of a longshot because of litigation, what tools does a Trump administration have to enforce it?
So they don't have much at all - not really anything.

In there, they say that they're going to put together a list of companies that don't meet the standards and shame them, and then they're going to expect the other companies to sue each other or consumers to sue the companies - so no real tools.
Feels more political than substantive.
Sarah Jane Tribble, senior correspondent with Kaiser Health News, thank you so much.
Thank you.
From NPR News, this is NEWS AND NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
Conflict in the Middle East has dominated recent headlines.
But unrest in Somalia could soon destabilize much of East Africa.
Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, was recently seized by the Supreme Islamic Courts Council.
When that militant group's troops appeared to threaten Somalia's young government, neighboring Ethiopia stepped in.
Peace talks have since sputtered and now two countries with a history of brutal conflict stand on the verge yet again.
In terms of thinking about how to really figure out the genetic roots of this disease.
Especially in film, you know, it's all about, you know, changing characters.
So, you know, if people--they've seen me as Andre 3000, you know--this wild and crazy type of character.
I guess it's hard for some casting directors or, you know, filmmakers to see that I may have something, you know, else to offer.
That's why I felt like the ""Four Brothers"" role was, you know, key to the beginning of my career, just to show, you know, that I could do a little bit more.
I understand--I read somewhere that when you read the script you immediately fell in love with it.
Is that true?
Yeah.
I thought the story was great.

I thought the story of the four brothers, you know, being that two of them were black, two of them were white--I thought it was kind of strange at first and I thought it was kind of kooky, and that kind of attracted me in a certain sense.
Andre, if you would, give me the plot for ""Four Brothers.
Yeah, ""Four Brothers,"" two black guys, two white guys, we were adopted when we were kids; we grew up on the streets of Detroit.
And the lady that adopted us--she was killed; she was murdered.
And the police say it was a random shooting.
So when my brothers come into town to attend the funeral, we find out that that wasn't the case and we have to dig, dig further and further and deeper and deeper.
And we find out, you know, things that we didn't want to find out.
And I really don't want to give away the story a lot, but you have to just pay attention to what's going on.
You have to pay attention to, I guess, the development of the story.
So much has been made of musicians, singers, etc., coming in and being seen as commodities, if you will, to help move a movie.
How do you consider yourself?
Do you consider yourself a musician first, an actor, or just an entertainer?
I guess an idealist, you know, pretty much a dreamer, you know.

We were kids, we grew up in, I guess, a renaissance age where, you know, we were born around the same time a lot of the great American companies were born: companies, you know, like Apple and, you know, Ralph Lauren, that company, and some of the, I guess, greatest ad campaigns; and, you know, the MTV age, age of video.
So I think we had so much; we were given so much, you know--you know, visually.
And we heard so much that I'm kind of like giving it back, you know.
I'm--I love film, you know.
I love music.
I love creating.
I love creating ad campaigns.
I love designing clothes, you know, even, you know, the clothes in the videos and on stage and clothes that I wear in the street, you know--normal sportswear.
You know, it's clothes that I've design so I'm even looking forward to building my brand.
Now what about the fans who know and love you for your music?
So many people concern themselves with the--if one becomes popular and does well in film, we may not see you back in the studio turning out music.
Do you ever see yourself letting that go?
